elements.content: High separation efficiency is very important for process of pressure swing adsorption (PSA) in the industry. Herein, we propose a fine design of chemically stable porous coordination polymers (PCPs) with optimized nanochannel by strategy of inserting and shifting shortest alkyl group on T-shaped ligand. Remarkably, the synergistic effect of optimized nanochannel, unique crystal morphology and fitted channel enable sharply enhanced breakthrough efficiency of C2H6/4/CH4, 1.17 or 0.77 g of CH4 can be separated from corresponding dual mixtures (2/8, v/v) by 1 g of NTU-25 at 273 K, which was further validated and understood by controlled experiments and density functional theory (DFT) computations.
elements.clean_text: High separation efficiency is very important for process of pressure swing adsorption (PSA) in the industry. Herein, we propose a fine design of chemically stable porous coordination polymers (PCPs) with optimized nanochannel by strategy of inserting and shifting shortest alkyl group on T-shaped ligand. Remarkably, the synergistic effect of optimized nanochannel, unique crystal morphology and fitted channel enable sharply enhanced breakthrough efficiency of C2H6/4/CH4, 1.17 or 0.77 g of CH4 can be separated from corresponding dual mixtures (2/8, v/v) by 1 g of NTU-25 at 273 K, which was further validated and understood by controlled experiments and density functional theory (DFT) computations.

elements.content: The relative abundance of CH4 in our world makes it a most crucial starting material and energy source for modern industry and social life. Converting CH4 to C2H4 would offer enormous economic benefits, whereas the wide usage of CH4 could alleviate the environment pollution by nearly 100% on SO2 and dust emission. However, the geochemical streams commonly contain high concentration of CO2 and C2 hydrocarbons, which may hinder the value-added conversion or lead pipeline corrosion. Thus, selective removal of CO2 and C2 hydrocarbons is an important process for natural gas upgrading. To date, worldwide efforts focused on developing suitable material for PSA technology, as conventional and current alternatives (compression/cryogenic distillation) carry high risks with higher energy cost.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The relative abundance of CH4 in our world makes it a most crucial starting material and energy source for modern industry and social life. Converting CH4 to C2H4 would offer enormous economic benefits, whereas the wide usage of CH4 could alleviate the environment pollution by nearly 100% on SO2 and dust emission. However, the geochemical streams commonly contain high concentration of CO2 and C2 hydrocarbons, which may hinder the value-added conversion or lead pipeline corrosion. Thus, selective removal of CO2 and C2 hydrocarbons is an important process for natural gas upgrading. To date, worldwide efforts focused on developing suitable material for PSA technology, as conventional and current alternatives (compression/cryogenic distillation) carry high risks with higher energy cost.

elements.content: PCPs that assembled from organic ligands and inorganic clusters were believed as the most promising candidate for CH4 purification because their pore environment can be facilely designed and prepared. With rapid development in the last two decades, a few of them with functional pore surface showed high gas selectivity of C2H6/4 and CO2 toward CH4 based on their single adsorption isotherms, or the possible separation from breakthrough experiments. However, as the crucial factors for PSA process, breakthrough efficiency, a newly defined concept for identifying how much amount gas can be purified by per unit adsorbent in a single breakthrough operation, was not well investigated. For improving the breakthrough efficiency, higher gas adsorption and rational molecular diffusion within the framework are considered as the most important factors. Ideally, the pore with a large inner diameter can hold enhanced capacity, whereas the most suitable channel will broaden the significant gap during gas diffusion. In addition, the robustness of the framework under chemical environment is also highly required. Therefore, the challenges we now face became more practical in nature, i.e., how to integrate those factors in a single domain.
elements.clean_text: PCPs that assembled from organic ligands and inorganic clusters were believed as the most promising candidate for CH4 purification because their pore environment can be facilely designed and prepared. With rapid development in the last two decades, a few of them with functional pore surface showed high gas selectivity of C2H6/4 and CO2 toward CH4  based on their single adsorption isotherms, or the possible separation from breakthrough experiments. However, as the crucial factors for PSA process, breakthrough efficiency, a newly defined concept for identifying how much amount gas can be purified by per unit adsorbent in a single breakthrough operation, was not well investigated. For improving the breakthrough efficiency, higher gas adsorption and rational molecular diffusion within the framework are considered as the most important factors. Ideally, the pore with a large inner diameter can hold enhanced capacity, whereas the most suitable channel will broaden the significant gap during gas diffusion. In addition, the robustness of the framework under chemical environment is also highly required. Therefore, the challenges we now face became more practical in nature, i.e., how to integrate those factors in a single domain.

elements.content: We are interested in design and synthesis of functional porous materials for energy gas separation. Herein, a new PCP (NTU-23) with T-shaped ligand and Cu dimers was prepared, as well as its −CH3 inserted derivative (NTU-24) and −CH3 shifted analogue (NTU-25) (). By integrating the characters of high porosity and good chemical stabilities (2 < pH < 12 at 373 K), NTU-25 has two kinds of alternative pores and −CH3 modified nanochannel. More importantly, gas adsorption and breakthrough experiments showed that 1 g of NTU-25 can produce 1.17 or 0.77 g of pure CH4 from corresponding C2H6/4/CH4 mixtures (2/8, v/v) at 273 K. According to the controlled experiments and DFT study, this significant breakthrough efficiency should be assigned as the synergistic effect of −CH3 defined nanochannel and unique crystal morphology.
elements.clean_text: We are interested in design and synthesis of functional porous materials for energy gas separation. Herein, a new PCP (NTU-23) with T-shaped ligand and Cu dimers was prepared, as well as its -CH3 inserted derivative (NTU-24) and -CH3 shifted analogue (NTU-25) (). By integrating the characters of high porosity and good chemical stabilities (2 < pH < 12 at 373 K), NTU-25 has two kinds of alternative pores and -CH3 modified nanochannel. More importantly, gas adsorption and breakthrough experiments showed that 1 g of NTU-25 can produce 1.17 or 0.77 g of pure CH4 from corresponding C2H6/4/CH4 mixtures (2/8, v/v) at 273 K. According to the controlled experiments and DFT study, this significant breakthrough efficiency should be assigned as the synergistic effect of -CH3 defined nanochannel and unique crystal morphology.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received. General procedures and details of adsorption experiments, spectroscopic techniques, structure details, controlled experiments and calculation studies are provided in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Materials

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received. General procedures and details of adsorption experiments, spectroscopic techniques, structure details, controlled experiments and calculation studies are provided in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: CuBr2 (18 mg, 0.080 mmol), H2NL1 (4 mg, 0.012 mmol) and HBr (30 μL) were mixed with 2 mL of N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF)/H2O (4:1) in a 10 mL glass container and tightly capped with a Teflon vial and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. After temperature cooling down, green polyhedral crystals with high yield were harvested and washed by DMF. Anal. Calcd (Found) for [C17H10CuN2O4]: C, 55.21 (55.58) H, 2.73 (2.64) N, 7.57 (7.96).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of NTU-23

CuBr2 (18 mg, 0.080 mmol), H2NL1 (4 mg, 0.012 mmol) and HBr (30 μL) were mixed with 2 mL of N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF)/H2O (4:1) in a 10 mL glass container and tightly capped with a Teflon vial and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. After temperature cooling down, green polyhedral crystals with high yield were harvested and washed by DMF. Anal. Calcd (Found) for [C17H10CuN2O4]: C, 55.21 (55.58) H, 2.73 (2.64) N, 7.57 (7.96).

After temperature cooling down, the green polyhedral crystals with high yield were harvested and washed by DMF. Anal. Calcd (Found) for [C18H12CuN2O4]: C, 56.32 (56.02); H, 3.15 (3.04); N, 7.30 (7.52).

CuBr2 (18 mg, 0.080 mmol), H2NL2 (4 mg, 0.012 mmol) and HBr (30 μL) were mixed with 2 mL of DMF/H2O (4:1) in a 10 mL glass container and tightly capped with a Teflon vial and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. After temperature cooling down, the green polyhedral crystals with high yield were harvested and washed by DMF. Anal. elements.content: CuBr2 (18 mg, 0.08 mmol), H2NL3 (4 mg, 0.012 mmol), and HBr (30 μL) were mixed with 2 mL of DMF/H2O (6:1) in a 10 mL glass container and tightly capped with a Teflon vial and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. After cooling down, the green polyhedral crystals with high yield were harvested and washed by DMF. Anal. Calcd (Found) for [C18H12CuN2O4]: C, 56.32 (55.95); H, 3.15 (2.96) N; 7.30 (7.68).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of NTU-25

CuBr2 (18 mg, 0.08 mmol), H2NL3 (4 mg, 0.012 mmol), and HBr (30 μL) were mixed with 2 mL of DMF/H2O (6:1) in a 10 mL glass container and tightly capped with a Teflon vial and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. After cooling down, the green polyhedral crystals with high yield were harvested and washed by DMF. Anal. Calcd (Found) for [C18H12CuN2O4]: C, 56.32 (55.95); H, 3.15 (2.96) N; 7.30 (7.68).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were measured on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer at 298 K using graphite monochromated Mo/Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals (Figure S1) of NTU-23 to -25 were mounted on the top of the glass fiber for data collection. The structures were then solved by direct methods and refined using the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXTL package. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters during the final cycles. Organic hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions with isotropic displacement parameters set to 1.2 Ueq of the attached atom. Due to high disordered solvent molecules in the unit cells, we employed PLATON/SQUEEZE to calculate the diffraction contribution of the solvent molecules, and thereby, to produce a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The structure was then refined again using the data generated. Crystallographic data of NTU-23 to -25 can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via the link of https://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/structures/. CCDC number: 1855699–1855701.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Studies

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were measured on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer at 298 K using graphite monochromated Mo/Kα radiation (λ =  0.71073 Å). The crystals (Figure S1) of NTU-23 to -25 were mounted on the top of the glass fiber for data collection. The structures were then solved by direct methods and refined using the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXTL package. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters during the final cycles. Organic hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions with isotropic displacement parameters set to 1.2 Ueq of the attached atom. Due to high disordered solvent molecules in the unit cells, we employed PLATON/SQUEEZE to calculate the diffraction contribution of the solvent molecules, and thereby, to produce a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The structure was then refined again using the data generated. Crystallographic data of NTU-23 to -25 can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via the link of https://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/structures/. CCDC number: 1855699-1855701.

elements.content: The breakthrough system used in this study is handmade according to the literatures. The flow rates of all gases are regulated by mass flow controllers, and the effluent gas stream from the column is monitored by a gas chromatography (GC). Activated NTU-24 or NTU-25 was packed into a stainless-steel column (12 cm length ×0.30 cm internal diameter). The packed column was initially purged with helium gas for 30 min until no other gases were detected in the effluent. Then, a CH4 flow and CO2 flow (or C2 hydrocarbon flow) (total is 10 mL/min: 5:5 or 8:2) were dosed into the column. A breakthrough of CH4 was determined when the concentration of effluent CH4 reached 1% of the feed concentration. In addition, the breakthrough experiment with water vapor (5%) was performed at 298 K for avoiding water condensation. Breakthrough times were calculated by subtracting the time to breakthrough using a sample bed packed only with stainless steel beads and cotton plugs from the observed breakthrough time.
elements.clean_text:
Measurement of Breakthrough Curves

The breakthrough system used in this study is handmade according to the literatures. The flow rates of all gases are regulated by mass flow controllers, and the effluent gas stream from the column is monitored by a gas chromatography (GC). Activated NTU-24 or NTU-25 was packed into a stainless-steel column (12 cm length ×0.30 cm internal diameter). The packed column was initially purged with helium gas for 30 min until no other gases were detected in the effluent. Then, a CH4 flow and CO2 flow (or C2 hydrocarbon flow) (total is 10 mL/min: 5:5 or 8:2) were dosed into the column. A breakthrough of CH4 was determined when the concentration of effluent CH4 reached 1% of the feed concentration. In addition, the breakthrough experiment with water vapor (5%) was performed at 298 K for avoiding water condensation. Breakthrough times were calculated by subtracting the time to breakthrough using a sample bed packed only with stainless steel beads and cotton plugs from the observed breakthrough time.

elements.content:
All DFT computations were performed with the Gaussian 09 package For the calculations of different properties, different levels of theories can be found in the Supporting Information

Results and DiscussionStructural Analysis

Reaction of 4′-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-[1,1′-biphenyl]-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2NL1 ) and CuBr2 in DMF/H2O afforded crystalline and polyhedral crystals, [Cu­(NL1 )] n ·xSolvent, (termed as NTU-23). The symmetric unit of it consists of one ligand and one Cu2+. Each Cu2+ is five-coordinated with four oxygen atoms from four independent carboxylate groups and one N-donor from the imidazole motif of the fifth ligand. The two Cu2+ ions adopt the paddle-wheel unit. From the perspective of this linkage, every ligand links to three paddle-wheels and each paddle-wheel connects six ligands (Figure S2a–c). Therefore, the whole structure can be simplified as a (3, 6)-c eea net (Figure S2m). NTU-23 has two kinds of alternative cages. The inner sphere diameter of ball-liked cage expands to 8 Å, while the parameter of spindle-cage is 18 Å for length and 8 Å for maximum diameter. The alternative arrangement of the two cages forms hourglass-shaped channel along with side open window (the pore along 0 9 64 plane) along c-axis ( and Figure S2d). Calculated by PLATON, the total accessible volume of NTU-23 reached to 55.9% upon guest removal with a crystallographic density of 0.887 g cm–3.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Computations

All DFT computations were performed with the Gaussian 09 package For the calculations of different properties, different levels of theories can be found in the Supporting Information 

Results and Discussion

Structural Analysis

Reaction of 4'-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-[1,1'-biphenyl]-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2NL1 ) and CuBr2 in DMF/H2O afforded crystalline and polyhedral crystals, [Cu(NL1 )] n ⋅xSolvent, (termed as NTU-23). The symmetric unit of it consists of one ligand and one Cu2+. Each Cu2+ is five-coordinated with four oxygen atoms from four independent carboxylate groups and one N-donor from the imidazole motif of the fifth ligand. The two Cu2+ ions adopt the paddle-wheel unit. From the perspective of this linkage, every ligand links to three paddle-wheels and each paddle-wheel connects six ligands (Figure S2a-c). Therefore, the whole structure can be simplified as a (3, 6)-c eea net (Figure S2m). NTU-23 has two kinds of alternative cages. The inner sphere diameter of ball-liked cage expands to 8 Å, while the parameter of spindle-cage is 18 Å for length and 8 Å for maximum diameter. The alternative arrangement of the two cages forms hourglass-shaped channel along with side open window (the pore along 0 9 64 plane) along c-axis ( and Figure S2d). Calculated by PLATON, the total accessible volume of NTU-23 reached to 55.9% upon guest removal with a crystallographic density of 0.887 g cm-3.

elements.content: Alternative packing of two cages forms hourglass-shaped channel along with side open window in NTU-23.
elements.clean_text: 1  Alternative packing of two cages forms hourglass-shaped channel along with side open window in NTU-23.

elements.content: Inspired by the above hourglass-shaped channel, we want to introduce further optimized channel neck, as it would benefit the separation capability and efficiency. The significant cage will allow increased adsorption, while, the fitted neck will widen the gap during molecules diffusion. By inserting and shifting the –CH3 group around imidazole motif of H2NL1 , another two analogue PCPs (NTU-24 and NTU-25) were synthesized by the coordination of Cu2+ ion and corresponded ligands of 4′-(2-methyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)-[1,1′-biphenyl]-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2NL2 ) and 4′-(4-methyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)-[1,1′-biphenyl]-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2NL3 ). Single-crystal X-ray diffractions showed that NTU-24 and NTU-25 are isostructures of NTU-23 (Figure S2e-l, Table S1). As shown in , different location of −CH3 brought slight changes of the channels. For NTU-24, the −CH3 groups point against the neck of the channel, and keep path same as that of NTU-23. However, after shifting the −CH3 to 4′-position on imidazole unit, the three −CH3 groups stretch into cage B in NTU-25, inducing the blocked channel. Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD) reflected that all three PCPs have good crystallinity and phase purity (Figure S3–S5). Thermalgravimetric analysis showed that all samples are thermally stable up to about 300 °C (Figure S6–S8).
elements.clean_text: Inspired by the above hourglass-shaped channel, we want to introduce further optimized channel neck, as it would benefit the separation capability and efficiency. The significant cage will allow increased adsorption, while, the fitted neck will widen the gap during molecules diffusion. By inserting and shifting the -CH3 group around imidazole motif of H2NL1 , another two analogue PCPs (NTU-24 and NTU-25) were synthesized by the coordination of Cu2+ ion and corresponded ligands of 4'-(2-methyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)-[1,1'-biphenyl]-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2NL2 ) and 4'-(4-methyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)-[1,1'-biphenyl]-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2NL3 ). Single-crystal X-ray diffractions showed that NTU-24 and NTU-25 are isostructures of NTU-23 (Figure S2e-l, Table S1). As shown in , different location of -CH3 brought slight changes of the channels. For NTU-24, the -CH3 groups point against the neck of the channel, and keep path same as that of NTU-23. However, after shifting the -CH3 to 4'-position on imidazole unit, the three -CH3 groups stretch into cage B in NTU-25, inducing the blocked channel. Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD) reflected that all three PCPs have good crystallinity and phase purity (Figure S3-S5). Thermalgravimetric analysis showed that all samples are thermally stable up to about 300 °C (Figure S6-S8).

elements.content: An illustration of nanochannel modification in NTU-24 and -25 by methyl inserting and site shifting upon the pristine structure of NTU-23.
elements.clean_text: 2  An illustration of nanochannel modification in NTU-24 and -25 by methyl inserting and site shifting upon the pristine structure of NTU-23.

elements.content: Bearing the cluster protection from hydrophobic −CH3 and the N coordination in axial, we therefore studied the chemical stability of the three PCPs. All PCPs were treated under chemical solutions with varied pH. From PXRD analysis, we found that the lost diffraction reveals that NTU-23 is not stable in water and even worse in chemical solutions at 25 °C. Specifically, NTU-24 can retain its structure after being immersed in water with pH = 2 and 7, at 60 °C, however, the crystallinity gradually lost after keeping it in basic solution (Figure S12–13). Comparably, NTU-25 kept good crystallinity in water for 45 days at 25 °C, as well as harsh condition with wide pH range (2 < pH< 12) at 100 °C (a and Figure S14). Further N2 adsorption isotherms showed that the porosity of base- and water-treated NTU-25 are fully the same as that of the fresh sample, but decreased ∼20% for the acid-treated sample (b). Taking the structures in mind, the improved stability from NTU-23 to NTU-24 must arise from the inserted –CH3 that provides water erosion resistance in certain content. Moreover, three shifted −CH3 groups cooperate together to form a barrier at the channel neck in NTU-25, which strongly resists water to achieve the cluster and then induces good framework stability. Thus, they are new PCP members that have good chemical stability, governed by the inserted −CH3 group.
elements.clean_text:
Chemical Stability Test

Bearing the cluster protection from hydrophobic -CH3 and the N coordination in axial, we therefore studied the chemical stability of the three PCPs. All PCPs were treated under chemical solutions with varied pH. From PXRD analysis, we found that the lost diffraction reveals that NTU-23 is not stable in water and even worse in chemical solutions at 25 °C. Specifically, NTU-24 can retain its structure after being immersed in water with pH =  2 and 7, at 60 °C, however, the crystallinity gradually lost after keeping it in basic solution (Figure S12-13). Comparably, NTU-25 kept good crystallinity in water for 45 days at 25 °C, as well as harsh condition with wide pH range (2 < pH< 12) at 100 °C (a and Figure S14). Further N2 adsorption isotherms showed that the porosity of base- and water-treated NTU-25 are fully the same as that of the fresh sample, but decreased ~20% for the acid-treated sample (b). Taking the structures in mind, the improved stability from NTU-23 to NTU-24 must arise from the inserted -CH3 that provides water erosion resistance in certain content. Moreover, three shifted -CH3 groups cooperate together to form a barrier at the channel neck in NTU-25, which strongly resists water to achieve the cluster and then induces good framework stability. Thus, they are new PCP members that have good chemical stability, governed by the inserted -CH3 group.

elements.content: (a) PXRD of chemically treated NTU-25, (b) N2 adsorption isotherms (77 K) of water and chemically treated (100 °C for 24 h) NTU-25.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) PXRD of chemically treated NTU-25, (b) N2 adsorption isotherms (77 K) of water and chemically treated (100 °C for 24 h) NTU-25.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of NTU-23 to -25 was confirmed by N2 adsorptions at 77 K (Figure S15). The saturated N2 uptake reached to 457 cm3 g–1 in NTU-23, indicating a BET surface area of ca. 1850 m2 g–1. N2 adsorptions of NTU-24 and NTU-25 showed a slight decrease to 405 and 398 cm3 g–1, respectively, as well as the decreased pore volume from 0.716 (NTU-23) to 0.628 (NTU-24) and 0.611 cm3 g–1 (NTU-25), validating the existence of inserted −CH3 groups. Due to good porosity and improved stability, single gas adsorption experiments were carried out on NTU-24 and NTU-25 at 273 K up to 100 kPa. As shown in a-b, both NTU-24 and NTU-25 preferentially adsorbs more CO2 (5.0 mmol g–1) and C2H6/4 (∼5.5–6.2 mmol g–1) than that of CH4 (1.4–1.5 mmol g–1). This is also reflected in the calculated adsorption enthalpies, of which CH4 exhibits the lowest values at all loading range (Figure S16–S20).
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption, Selectivity, and Separation

The permanent porosity of NTU-23 to -25 was confirmed by N2 adsorptions at 77 K (Figure S15). The saturated N2 uptake reached to 457 cm3 g-1 in NTU-23, indicating a BET surface area of ca. 1850 m2 g-1. N2 adsorptions of NTU-24 and NTU-25 showed a slight decrease to 405 and 398 cm3 g-1, respectively, as well as the decreased pore volume from 0.716 (NTU-23) to 0.628 (NTU-24) and 0.611 cm3 g-1 (NTU-25), validating the existence of inserted -CH3 groups. Due to good porosity and improved stability, single gas adsorption experiments were carried out on NTU-24 and NTU-25 at 273 K up to 100 kPa. As shown in a-b, both NTU-24 and NTU-25 preferentially adsorbs more CO2 (5.0 mmol g-1) and C2H6/4 (~5.5-6.2 mmol g-1) than that of CH4 (1.4-1.5 mmol g-1). This is also reflected in the calculated adsorption enthalpies, of which CH4 exhibits the lowest values at all loading range (Figure S16-S20).

elements.content: Gas adsorption isotherms (points) and dual-site Langmuir–Freundlich fit lines (lines) of the four gases in (a) NTU-24 and (b) NTU-25 at 273 K; (c) IAST predicted gas selectivity. Breakthrough curves of (d) NTU-24 crystal, (e) NTU-25 crystal and (f) NTU-25 microparticle with a gas ratio of 20/80 at 273 K. The breakthrough time of the all samples was normalized to 1g for easy comparison from 702 mg of NTU-24 crystal, 651 mg of NTU-25 crystal and 510 mg of NTU-25 microparticle according to the reported method.
elements.clean_text: 4  Gas adsorption isotherms (points) and dual-site Langmuir-Freundlich fit lines (lines) of the four gases in (a) NTU-24 and (b) NTU-25 at 273 K; (c) IAST predicted gas selectivity. Breakthrough curves of (d) NTU-24 crystal, (e) NTU-25 crystal and (f) NTU-25 microparticle with a gas ratio of 20/80 at 273 K. The breakthrough time of the all samples was normalized to 1g for easy comparison from 702 mg of NTU-24 crystal, 651 mg of NTU-25 crystal and 510 mg of NTU-25 microparticle according to the reported method.

elements.content: To predict the binary mixture selectivity, we employed an ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) calculation on the basis of these isotherms. As shown in c, the selectivities for C2H6/4/CH4 of NTU-25 are both higher than those of NTU-24, with the values of 16 and 31, respectively. These values are also higher than those of series of important PCPs, such as LaBTB (8.0 and 11.8), FIR-7a-ht (8.6 and 14.6), MFM-202a (8 and 10) and UTSA-35a (10 and 20) at similar conditions. Further stable adsorption abilities were also confirmed by dynamic CO2 adsorption in 10 cycles (Figure S21).
elements.clean_text: To predict the binary mixture selectivity, we employed an ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) calculation on the basis of these isotherms. As shown in c, the selectivities for C2H6/4/CH4 of NTU-25 are both higher than those of NTU-24, with the values of 16 and 31, respectively. These values are also higher than those of series of important PCPs, such as LaBTB (8.0 and 11.8), FIR-7a-ht (8.6 and 14.6), MFM-202a (8 and 10) and UTSA-35a (10 and 20) at similar conditions. Further stable adsorption abilities were also confirmed by dynamic CO2 adsorption in 10 cycles (Figure S21).

elements.content: To confirm these observations, we performed breakthrough experiments on NTU-24 and NTU-25 under continuous and flowing conditions. The fully activated samples were initially swept by He flow. After initial dosing of CO2/CH4 mixture, the concentration of 100% for CH4 and 0% for CO2 were detected by gas chromatography (GC), until the breakpoint at 55 and 60 min (d–f). When changing the feed gas to C2H4/CH4 or C2H6/CH4, the breakpoints were significantly extended to 118 and 200 min in NTU-24, 158, and 240 min in NTU-25. Remarkably, from the sample weight, outlet gas flow speed (10 mL·min–1) and working condition, we can calculate that 1 g of NTU-25 can produce 1.17 or 0.77 g of pure CH4 from C2H6/4/CH4 mixtures at 273 K. Compare with other important PCPs that summarized in Table S2, NTU-25 showed sharply enhanced breakthrough efficiency. More importantly, the fully identical breakthrough curves were obtained after 20 min of He blowing at room temperature, meaning a very facile and mild protocol for sample regeneration (Figure S23, S25).
elements.clean_text: To confirm these observations, we performed breakthrough experiments on NTU-24 and NTU-25 under continuous and flowing conditions. The fully activated samples were initially swept by He flow. After initial dosing of CO2/CH4 mixture, the concentration of 100% for CH4 and 0% for CO2 were detected by gas chromatography (GC), until the breakpoint at 55 and 60 min (d-f). When changing the feed gas to C2H4/CH4 or C2H6/CH4, the breakpoints were significantly extended to 118 and 200 min in NTU-24, 158, and 240 min in NTU-25. Remarkably, from the sample weight, outlet gas flow speed (10 mL⋅min-1) and working condition, we can calculate that 1 g of NTU-25 can produce 1.17 or 0.77 g of pure CH4 from C2H6/4/CH4 mixtures at 273 K. Compare with other important PCPs that summarized in Table S2, NTU-25 showed sharply enhanced breakthrough efficiency. More importantly, the fully identical breakthrough curves were obtained after 20 min of He blowing at room temperature, meaning a very facile and mild protocol for sample regeneration (Figure S23, S25).

elements.content: For further validating the framework stability, breakthrough experiments with and without 5% water vapor were performed on NTU-25 crystal at 298 K. As shown in , breakthrough time of CH4/C2H6 flow that contains 5% water vapor is fully same in the two-rounded experiments. Importantly, this time is also same as the breakthrough time with dry CH4/C2H6 flow. Therefore, the results suggested that the porous framework of NTU-25 is strong enough to resist vapor erosion during dynamic separation process. As well, these results confirmed again that NTU-25 is a very promising candidate for feasible CH4 purification.
elements.clean_text: For further validating the framework stability, breakthrough experiments with and without 5% water vapor were performed on NTU-25 crystal at 298 K. As shown in , breakthrough time of CH4/C2H6 flow that contains 5% water vapor is fully same in the two-rounded experiments. Importantly, this time is also same as the breakthrough time with dry CH4/C2H6 flow. Therefore, the results suggested that the porous framework of NTU-25 is strong enough to resist vapor erosion during dynamic separation process. As well, these results confirmed again that NTU-25 is a very promising candidate for feasible CH4 purification.

elements.content: Breakthrough curves of NTU-25 crystals with and without water vapor (5%) at 298 K. The breakthrough time was also normalized to 1g from 451 mg (fully activated NTU-25).
elements.clean_text: 5  Breakthrough curves of NTU-25 crystals with and without water vapor (5%) at 298 K. The breakthrough time was also normalized to 1g from 451 mg (fully activated NTU-25).

elements.content: To reveal the reason for the current gas separation, we estimated the involved effective pore size through the charge density surface, which was directly calculated from their wave functions, corresponding to the van der Waals radii (). The effective molecular size is 4.54, 5.88, 5.85, and 6.06 Å on the xy-plane, whereas it is 4.55, 4.53, 4.24, and 3.27 Å on the yz-plane for CH4, C2H6, C2H4, and CO2, respectively. The channel along the 0 0 1 plane has no space for any of the molecules to go through. The longest length of the channel along b-axis is also too short, ∼1.22 Å, for the four molecules to pass. In contrast, the channel along the 0 9 64 plane shown in c has enough space (∼4.88 Å in diameter) where all the molecules can diffuse. We however emphasize that C2H6, C2H4, and CO2 have to align their molecular axes to the axis of the channel along 0 9 64 plane to pass there while CH4 can go through the channel almost freely with any molecular orientation. This molecular-axis dependent gas diffusion clearly rationalizes the present unprecedented gas separation, shown in d, e. The observed separation efficiency in the order of C2H6, C2H4, and CO2 reflects the effective molecular size on the yz-plane in the order of C2H6, C2H4, and CO2, supporting the current molecular-axis dependent separation picture. The current scenario holds also for NTU-24, except the small open channel along 0 0 1 plane, where the three −CH3 stretch against the bottleneck (Figure S27). It should be additionally noted that there should be no clogging effect caused by gas adsorption inside the channel of NTU-25 due to the limited diffusion as well as the originally weak adsorption interaction (Figure S28).
elements.clean_text:
DFT and Pore Size Calculation

To reveal the reason for the current gas separation, we estimated the involved effective pore size through the charge density surface, which was directly calculated from their wave functions, corresponding to the van der Waals radii (). The effective molecular size is 4.54, 5.88, 5.85, and 6.06 Å on the xy-plane, whereas it is 4.55, 4.53, 4.24, and 3.27 Å on the yz-plane for CH4, C2H6, C2H4, and CO2, respectively. The channel along the 0 0 1 plane has no space for any of the molecules to go through. The longest length of the channel along b-axis is also too short, ~1.22 Å, for the four molecules to pass. In contrast, the channel along the 0 9 64 plane shown in c has enough space (~4.88 Å in diameter) where all the molecules can diffuse. We however emphasize that C2H6, C2H4, and CO2 have to align their molecular axes to the axis of the channel along 0 9 64 plane to pass there while CH4 can go through the channel almost freely with any molecular orientation. This molecular-axis dependent gas diffusion clearly rationalizes the present unprecedented gas separation, shown in d, e. The observed separation efficiency in the order of C2H6, C2H4, and CO2 reflects the effective molecular size on the yz-plane in the order of C2H6, C2H4, and CO2, supporting the current molecular-axis dependent separation picture. The current scenario holds also for NTU-24, except the small open channel along 0 0 1 plane, where the three -CH3 stretch against the bottleneck (Figure S27). It should be additionally noted that there should be no clogging effect caused by gas adsorption inside the channel of NTU-25 due to the limited diffusion as well as the originally weak adsorption interaction (Figure S28).

elements.content: Effective size of channels along (a) 0 0 1 plane, (b) b-axis, and (c) 0 9 64 plane of NTU-25 as well as (d) the four molecules, estimated with the charge density which corresponds to the van der Waals radii. The effective molecular size is shown as dotted ellipses on the xy- and yz-planes.
elements.clean_text: 6  Effective size of channels along (a) 0 0 1 plane, (b) b-axis, and (c) 0 9 64 plane of NTU-25 as well as (d) the four molecules, estimated with the charge density which corresponds to the van der Waals radii. The effective molecular size is shown as dotted ellipses on the xy- and yz-planes.

elements.content: Furthermore, crystal morphology analysis showed that the channel along 0 9 64 plane of NTU-25 was limited by the crossing of 0 0 1 and 0 1 0 planes (Figure S30–31). Therefore, the open pore along 0 0 1 plane is the main entrance for the gases. Due to the blocked channel by –CH3 groups along 0 0 1 plane, the entered gas molecules will enter the channel along 0 9 64 through the side window. In order to validate the above picture of the molecular-axis dependent gas diffusion, the controlled breakthrough experiments on grained microparticles (30 to 150 μm) of NTU-25 were performed (f and Figure S32). The breakthrough time of the all gas mixtures significantly decreased for the microparticles. The broken microparticles have more exposed channel along 0 9 64 plane in different directions and C2H6, C2H4, and CO2 can have more opportunity to align their molecular axes to the channel in the broken NTU-25 microparticles. Further, the breakthrough experiments on micropowder of ZIF-8 (1800 m2/g) and ZIF-70 (1730 m2/g), where these three PCPs have very similar surface area and particle size (Figure S35), showed that the breakthrough time for the grained NTU-25 microparticles remains much longer than the times of ZIF-8 (20 and 31 min) and ZIF-70 (34 and 54 min) (Figures S36 and S37), indicating the importance of its intrinsic pore of NTU-25 for gas separation.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, crystal morphology analysis showed that the channel along 0 9 64 plane of NTU-25 was limited by the crossing of 0 0 1 and 0 1 0 planes (Figure S30-31). Therefore, the open pore along 0 0 1 plane is the main entrance for the gases. Due to the blocked channel by -CH3 groups along 0 0 1 plane, the entered gas molecules will enter the channel along 0 9 64 through the side window. In order to validate the above picture of the molecular-axis dependent gas diffusion, the controlled breakthrough experiments on grained microparticles (30 to 150 μm) of NTU-25 were performed (f and Figure S32). The breakthrough time of the all gas mixtures significantly decreased for the microparticles. The broken microparticles have more exposed channel along 0 9 64 plane in different directions and C2H6, C2H4, and CO2 can have more opportunity to align their molecular axes to the channel in the broken NTU-25 microparticles. Further, the breakthrough experiments on micropowder of ZIF-8 (1800 m2/g) and ZIF-70 (1730 m2/g), where these three PCPs have very similar surface area and particle size (Figure S35), showed that the breakthrough time for the grained NTU-25 microparticles remains much longer than the times of ZIF-8 (20 and 31 min) and ZIF-70 (34 and 54 min) (Figures S36 and S37), indicating the importance of its intrinsic pore of NTU-25 for gas separation.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully designed and prepared two chemically stable PCPs with optimized nanochannel by the strategy of inserting or shifting methyl group on T-shaped ligands. Remarkably, the synergistic effect of nanospace, crystal morphology and optimized pore leads to the significantly improved breakthrough efficiency of C2/C1 hydrocarbons by NTU-25. Our experimental and computational studies not only provide an optimal material with exceptional ability for CH4 purification, but also create a new concept for designing of feasible PCP adsorbents.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully designed and prepared two chemically stable PCPs with optimized nanochannel by the strategy of inserting or shifting methyl group on T-shaped ligands. Remarkably, the synergistic effect of nanospace, crystal morphology and optimized pore leads to the significantly improved breakthrough efficiency of C2/C1 hydrocarbons by NTU-25. Our experimental and computational studies not only provide an optimal material with exceptional ability for CH4 purification, but also create a new concept for designing of feasible PCP adsorbents.

cln_elements.content:
CuBr2 (18 mg, 0.080 mmol), H2NL1 (4 mg, 0.012 mmol) and HBr (30 μL) were mixed with 2 mL of N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF)/H2O (4:1) in a 10 mL glass container and tightly capped with a Teflon vial and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. After temperature cooling down, green polyhedral crystals with high yield were harvested and washed by DMF. Anal. Calcd (Found) for [C17H10CuN2O4]: C, 55.21 (55.58) H, 2.73 (2.64) N, 7.57 (7.96).

Synthesis of NTU-24

CuBr2 (18 mg, 0.080 mmol), H2NL2 (4 mg, 0.012 mmol) and HBr (30 μL) were mixed with 2 mL of DMF/H2O (4:1) in a 10 mL glass container and tightly capped with a Teflon vial and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. After temperature cooling down, the green polyhedral crystals with high yield were harvested and washed by DMF. Anal. Calcd (Found) for [C18H12CuN2O4]: C, 56.32 (56.02); H, 3.15 (3.04); N, 7.30 (7.52).

Synthesis of NTU-25

CuBr2 (18 mg, 0.08 mmol), H2NL3 (4 mg, 0.012 mmol), and HBr (30 μL) were mixed with 2 mL of DMF/H2O (6:1) in a 10 mL glass container and tightly capped with a Teflon vial and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. After cooling down, the green polyhedral crystals with high yield were harvested and washed by DMF. Anal. Calcd (Found) for [C18H12CuN2O4]: C, 56.32 (55.95); H, 3.15 (2.96) N; 7.30 (7.68).

cln_elements.content:
All DFT computations were performed with the Gaussian 09 package For the calculations of different properties, different levels of theories can be found in the Supporting Information

Results and DiscussionStructural Analysis

Reaction of 4′-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-[1,1′-biphenyl]-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2NL1 ) and CuBr2 in DMF/H2O afforded crystalline and polyhedral crystals, [Cu­(NL1 )] n ·xSolvent, (termed as NTU-23). The symmetric unit of it consists of one ligand and one Cu2+. Each Cu2+ is five-coordinated with four oxygen atoms from four independent carboxylate groups and one N-donor from the imidazole motif of the fifth ligand. The two Cu2+ ions adopt the paddle-wheel unit. From the perspective of this linkage, every ligand links to three paddle-wheels and each paddle-wheel connects six ligands (Figure S2a–c). Therefore, the whole structure can be simplified as a (3, 6)-c eea net (Figure S2m). NTU-23 has two kinds of alternative cages. The inner sphere diameter of ball-liked cage expands to 8 Å, while the parameter of spindle-cage is 18 Å for length and 8 Å for maximum diameter. The alternative arrangement of the two cages forms hourglass-shaped channel along with side open window (the pore along 0 9 64 plane) along c-axis ( and Figure S2d). Calculated by PLATON, the total accessible volume of NTU-23 reached to 55.9% upon guest removal with a crystallographic density of 0.887 g cm–3.

Gas Adsorption, Selectivity, and Separation

The permanent porosity of NTU-23 to -25 was confirmed by N2 adsorptions at 77 K (Figure S15). The saturated N2 uptake reached to 457 cm3 g–1 in NTU-23, indicating a BET surface area of ca. 1850 m2 g–1. N2 adsorptions of NTU-24 and NTU-25 showed a slight decrease to 405 and 398 cm3 g–1, respectively, as well as the decreased pore volume from 0.716 (NTU-23) to 0.628 (NTU-24) and 0.611 cm3 g–1 (NTU-25), validating the existence of inserted −CH3 groups. Due to good porosity and improved stability, single gas adsorption experiments were carried out on NTU-24 and NTU-25 at 273 K up to 100 kPa. As shown in a-b, both NTU-24 and NTU-25 preferentially adsorbs more CO2 (5.0 mmol g–1) and C2H6/4 (∼5.5–6.2 mmol g–1) than that of CH4 (1.4–1.5 mmol g–1). This is also reflected in the calculated adsorption enthalpies, of which CH4 exhibits the lowest values at all loading range (Figure S16–S20).
cln_elements.clean_text:
DFT Computations

All DFT computations were performed with the Gaussian 09 package For the calculations of different properties, different levels of theories can be found in the Supporting Information 

Results and Discussion

Structural Analysis

Reaction of 4'-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-[1,1'-biphenyl]-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2NL1 ) and CuBr2 in DMF/H2O afforded crystalline and polyhedral crystals, [Cu(NL1 )] n ⋅xSolvent, (termed as NTU-23). The symmetric unit of it consists of one ligand and one Cu2+. Each Cu2+ is five-coordinated with four oxygen atoms from four independent carboxylate groups and one N-donor from the imidazole motif of the fifth ligand. The two Cu2+ ions adopt the paddle-wheel unit. From the perspective of this linkage, every ligand links to three paddle-wheels and each paddle-wheel connects six ligands (Figure S2a-c). Therefore, the whole structure can be simplified as a (3, 6)-c eea net (Figure S2m). NTU-23 has two kinds of alternative cages. The inner sphere diameter of ball-liked cage expands to 8 Å, while the parameter of spindle-cage is 18 Å for length and 8 Å for maximum diameter. The alternative arrangement of the two cages forms hourglass-shaped channel along with side open window (the pore along 0 9 64 plane) along c-axis ( and Figure S2d). Calculated by PLATON, the total accessible volume of NTU-23 reached to 55.9% upon guest removal with a crystallographic density of 0.887 g cm-3.

Gas Adsorption, Selectivity, and Separation

The permanent porosity of NTU-23 to -25 was confirmed by N2 adsorptions at 77 K (Figure S15). The saturated N2 uptake reached to 457 cm3 g-1 in NTU-23, indicating a BET surface area of ca. 1850 m2 g-1. N2 adsorptions of NTU-24 and NTU-25 showed a slight decrease to 405 and 398 cm3 g-1, respectively, as well as the decreased pore volume from 0.716 (NTU-23) to 0.628 (NTU-24) and 0.611 cm3 g-1 (NTU-25), validating the existence of inserted -CH3 groups. Due to good porosity and improved stability, single gas adsorption experiments were carried out on NTU-24 and NTU-25 at 273 K up to 100 kPa. As shown in a-b, both NTU-24 and NTU-25 preferentially adsorbs more CO2 (5.0 mmol g-1) and C2H6/4 (~5.5-6.2 mmol g-1) than that of CH4 (1.4-1.5 mmol g-1). This is also reflected in the calculated adsorption enthalpies, of which CH4 exhibits the lowest values at all loading range (Figure S16-S20).

metadata.title:
Enhanced
Breakthrough Efficiency by a Chemically Stable Porous Coordination Polymer with Optimized Nanochannel
